newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Sweden's Asbrink says EU mins discused EIB role.
newsitem.headline: Sweden's Asbrink says EU mins discused EIB role.

text.p: Swedish Finance mInister Erik Asbrink said on Sunday that EU finance ministers had discussed the possibility of giving the European Investment Bank (EIB) a more active role.

Asbrink told reporters the issue had been discussed during talks on how to resolve a Franco-German rift that has emerged since France last week said it wanted more time to study the so-called stability pact. France said it wanted to give more emphasis to dealing with unemployment.

"Can we extend the scope of the bank's activities?... That is something we are looking at," Asbrink told reporters after the EU ministers held their talks over a dinner on the eve of a two-day summit of EU leaders in Amsterdam.

Asbrink said it was possible that the EIB would form part of a resolution on employment which was being negotiated by the finance ministers following the French demands for more emphasis on job creation in plans for monetary union (EMU).
The Swedish minister described Sunday's meeting as very positive and said it was very likely that the dispute over the stability pact would be resolved during the summit on Monday and Tuesday.
"It is unlikely that we would not agree," Asbrink said.

Asbrink also said the meeting had not discussed the issue of a stability council to give a political counterbalance to the future European Central Bank -- another French demand. He said that issue would be discussed during the Luxembourg EU presidency during the second half of 1997.
He said there had not been detailed discussion about funding for trans European rail and road networks. France had earlier suggested extra spending in this area as a way to boost jobs in Europe.
